* Liza Minnelli
* Nora Ephron
* Sean Astin

Putting Samsung’s “fake” moon photos to the test.

After a Redditor discovered that Samsung’s 100x “space zoom” feature may rely heavily on AI to spit out super crisp photos of the moon, YouTuber Marques Brownlee recreated the experiment with a Galaxy S23 Ultra.

His findings? Quite a bit less dramatic than what we saw on Reddit. The resulting moon photo seems equally as blurry as the original — save for some added brightness and sharpness — and doesn’t appear to add any details that weren’t there before.

www.youtube.com/watch?v=1afpDuTb-P0

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020 period, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Lotus Moon and Nandina Staff: The Art of Ōtagaki Rengetsu and Nakahara Nantenbō - Ackland Art Museum

last_post.content:
On March 31, the Ackland Art Museum here at UNC will open a small but wonderful exhibition on the work of Ōtagaki Rengetsu, a Buddhist woman calligrapher and potter from the 19th c., and Nakahara Nantenbō, a modern Zen calligrapher with close links to members of Japan's wartime military. I was lucky to be involved in the exhibition along with some brilliant graduate and undergraduate students from UNC. We had the chance to study many of the objects, help with translations, and contribute to conversations about the framing and planning of the exhibition itself. Please try to visit if you can. The show runs from March 31-June 11, 2023: https://ackland.org/exhibition/lotus-moon-and-nandina-staff-the-art-of-otagaki-rengetsu-and-nakahara-nantenbo/

Next is the actual data read step. The crucial part is filters. parquet is of course somewhat more optimized for storage for the full file, but the greatest strength is parquet's files on disk being aware of their content. The parquet file reader scans the header and decides if there is anything of value in this particular file, or it can be skipped.

# read the data
# filters: see https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/generated/pyarrow.parquet.read_table.html
auto1 = pd.read_parquet("sysauto",filters=[('foreign', '=', 1)])
